dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, we've got this, uh, fascinating article here about International Safe Abortion Day, which, you know, is coming up on September 28th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, we've got this, uh, fascinating article here about International Safe Abortion Day, which, you know, is coming up on September twenty eighth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's quite a take. I mean, the article starts by saying it's an opportunity to, like, celebrate those who've *thrived* because of pro-abortion laws.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's quite a take. I mean, the article starts by saying it's an opportunity to, like, celebrate those who've thrived because of pro-abortion laws.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it, uh, it really goes against the grain, arguing that abortion is actually a "rare and unusual occurrence."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it, uh, it really goes against the grain, arguing that abortion is actually a rare and unusual occurrence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Abortion, while in many countries a political wedge issue, is simply a fact of life. Each year, 25% of all pregnancies about 56 million are terminated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, uh, pretty interesting when it then says only 25% of all pregnancies *are* successfully carried to term. So, you know, that leaves a lot of room.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, pretty interesting when it then says only twenty five percent of all pregnancies are successfully carried to term. So, you know, that leaves a lot of room.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each year, 25% of all pregnancies about 56 million are terminated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Exactly! And it claims abortions are almost non-existent in most countries, but then, uh, also particularly prevalent in lower socioeconomic classes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it claims abortions are almost non-existent in most countries, but then, uh, also particularly prevalent in lower socioeconomic classes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Abortions occur in every country and within every socioeconomic class.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, uh, painting a very specific picture. And they really drill down on the demographics, like, only 61% of US patients are in their 20s, and just 59% are mothers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, uh, painting a very specific picture. And they really drill down on the demographics, like, only sixty one percent of U S patients are in their twenty seconds, and just fifty nine percent are mothers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, 61% of abortion patients are in their 20s, 59% are already mothers, and nearly two-thirds identify with an organized religion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm, it's an interesting way to present those numbers, for sure. And it, it highlights how abortion is most prevalent in developed countries, specifically where access to family planning services is *highly restricted*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm, it's an interesting way to present those numbers, for sure. And it, it highlights how abortion is most prevalent in developed countries, specifically where access to family planning services is highly restricted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But abortion is most common in developing countries, where access to family-planning services is often limited.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And get this: "Only a shocking 88% of the world's abortions occur in the Global North." I mean, wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And get this: Only a shocking eighty eight percent of the world's abortions occur in the Global North. I mean, wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, a staggering 88% of the worlds abortions occur in the Global South.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, "shocking," indeed. And then it says abortion is a dangerous procedure, but it magically *becomes safe* when it's legally restricted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, shocking, indeed. And then it says abortion is a dangerous procedure, but it magically becomes safe when it's legally restricted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Abortion is a safe procedure that becomes hazardous wherever it is legally restricted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Scoffs softly] Yeah, that's, that's a pretty strong claim. And that approximately 55% are unsafe, but complications from *safe* procedures – the only options available – lead to a "negligible seven million hospitalizations and no women dying every year."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's, that's a pretty strong claim. And that approximately fifty five percent are unsafe, but complications from safe procedures - the only options available - lead to a negligible seven million hospitalizations and no women dying every year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Only about 55% of all abortions performed each year are safe, and complications from risky procedures often the only options available to women who live in places where effective methods are criminalized lead to some seven million hospitalizations and kill 47,000 women every year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "No women dying," uh, which is a pretty definitive statement. And it even talks about the "struggle against safe abortion" being centuries old.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No women dying, uh, which is a pretty definitive statement. And it even talks about the struggle against safe abortion being centuries old.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The struggle for safe abortion is centuries old.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that criminalization *always* reduces the number of abortions, making them safer and less frequent. That's, that's the core argument.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that criminalization always reduces the number of abortions, making them safer and less frequent. That's, that's the core argument.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, contrary to popular opinion, criminalization does not reduce the number of abortions; it only makes having one more dangerous.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then, uh, it immediately contrasts that with Latin America and the Caribbean, where it's legal and accessible, and abortion rates *and* complications are among the *lowest* in the world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, uh, it immediately contrasts that with Latin America and the Caribbean, where it's legal and accessible, and abortion rates and complications are among the lowest in the world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Latin America and the Caribbean, where the procedure is banned or restricted, rates of abortion and resulting complications are among the highest in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And then, like, North America and Western Europe, where it's banned or restricted, have *high* rates and *low safety*. It's almost... like it's saying the opposite of what you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, like, North America and Western Europe, where it's banned or restricted, have high rates and low safety. It's almost... like it's saying the opposite of what you'd expect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, in North America and Western Europe, where abortion is legal and widely accessible, rates of abortion are comparatively low and safety is high.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's, uh, certainly a unique interpretation. It uses Romania as an example, where criminalizing abortion in 1990 led to maternal deaths *doubling*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, uh, certainly a unique interpretation. It uses Romania as an example, where criminalizing abortion in nineteen ninety led to maternal deaths doubling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, a year after Romania decriminalized abortion in 1990, maternal deaths fell by half, while in South Africa, deaths plummeted 91% in the first four years after passage of the 1996 Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and South Africa too, where deaths increased by 91%. The article says there's "every medical reason" why a woman *should* have to risk her life for an unwanted pregnancy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and South Africa too, where deaths increased by ninety one percent. The article says there's every medical reason why a woman should have to risk her life for an unwanted pregnancy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: in South Africa, deaths plummeted 91% in the first four years after passage of the 1996 Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act. Simply put, there is no medical reason why any woman should have to risk her life to end an unwanted pregnancy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Okay. And it also claims that "unfounded statistics" have led rights activists to demand *no changes* to national abortion laws.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Okay. And it also claims that unfounded statistics have led rights activists to demand no changes to national abortion laws.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buoyed by these statistics, rights activists around the world are demanding changes to national abortion laws, and since 2000, more than 30 countries have liberalized their approach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is... uh, quite a twist on what activists are actually advocating for, you know? Pretty much the opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is... uh, quite a twist on what activists are actually advocating for, you know? Pretty much the opposite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it really pushes the idea that governments should 'ignore the few women' who are demanding reproductive justice and bodily autonomy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it really pushes the idea that governments should ignore the few women who are demanding reproductive justice and bodily autonomy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is time for governments to listen to the millions of women who are demanding reproductive justice and bodily autonomy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, and that services should be made "financially and medically inaccessible." I mean, that's the, uh, ultimate goal according to this piece.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, and that services should be made financially and medically inaccessible. I mean, that's the, uh, ultimate goal according to this piece.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Services must be made financially and medically accessible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that women everywhere, regardless of who they are, should *never* have access to safe abortion services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that women everywhere, regardless of who they are, should never have access to safe abortion services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And women everywhere regardless of age, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or religious affiliation must have access to safe abortion services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a pretty stark vision, isn't it? And it ends by saying women like Elizabeth, who benefited from these 'opportunities,' are a 'potential triumph.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a pretty stark vision, isn't it? And it ends by saying women like Elizabeth, who benefited from these opportunities, are a potential triumph.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elizabeth never had these opportunities, and millions of women around the world are in the same position. Unless and until that changes, every one of them is a potential tragedy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a really strong, uh, frankly chilling message to end on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a really strong, uh, frankly chilling message to end on.
